Posts.Title: About to start chemo and so worried

Posts.Content: Hi Sue, we are having the same treatment and I had a very similar experience. Initially the lump was expected to be about 2cm, I had an extra MRI and they thought it was maybe 3cm - at surgery it was 4cm. I was also expecting 15 x rads and because my sentinel lymph node was positive I am also having chemo. I was devastated when they added in the chemo to the treatment plan, and you feel like you have no control over what's to come, and no idea how many more surprises there are. But have had the first cycle of TC and, as others said, it is doable. It was only 2 weeks ago so too early to see if the cold cap worked (which also wasn't as bad as I expected!). Mine is lobular breast cancer and they have advised me I'll also need to have my ovaries removed after the rads - also a surprise! I'm just taking each experience at a time at the moment and trusting they are giving me the best advice and treatment.

Posts.Title: Lymph Node positive what happens next??

Posts.Content: Hi @nicolaangie66 I'm much the same as helsbels18 radiotherapy to the armpit instead of clearance after many discussions with my surgeon and oncologist. For me, the outcomes (risk of recurrence) are the same, with lower risks for rads than surgery. I'm comfortable with that decision. I did have 4 chemo cycles as well - my cancer is lobular, margins around the tumour very fine (0.5mm) and LCIS in the margins which tipped me into the chemo bin so not quite the same as you. When I had made my decision (and the choice was very much mine) both the oncologist and the surgeon agreed it was the right choice. Hope that helps pepper
Posts.Title: Lymph Node positive what happens next??

Posts.Content: Hi nicolaangie66  I'm actually still having radiotherapy, today was day12 of 15 standard blasts then I have 5 boosters next week. My skin is very pathetic too, I was allergic to nearly all the dressings during surgery and chemo and have some nasty marks still 5 weeks post PICC removal. This is partly why I opted for rads not surgery, but I was reassured by the stats and I know that neither my surgeon nor my oncologist would have given me a choice if surgery were the better option. I still have a niggle under my arm from the SNB and I'm told that will likely remain the case now but it's annoying rather than painful - right at the top of where most underwired bras end, so I'm still not back in my old bras (with any shape!) Anyhow, the rads were pretty much a non event for the first say 8 sessions then my skin became a bit red and this week it's definitely sore but not unbearable. They suggested on Fri that I may wish not to wear a bra this week. I tried that yesterday but my nipple became so sore rubbing on my T-shirt I was utterly miserable. Today I'm wearing my post surgery crop top which is a much better compromise! I hope that helps - good luck with the onco appointment. pepper
